headline: Saudi Aramco Abruptly Drops Plans to Expand Oil Production
abstract: The pullback, at the behest of the Saudi government and made with little comment, probably reflects a more subdued outlook for demand of Saudi Arabia’s oil.
snippet: The pullback, at the behest of the Saudi government and made with little comment, probably reflects a more subdued outlook for demand of Saudi Arabia’s oil.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco said Tuesday that it would call off plans to expand its oil output, a remarkable turnaround by one of the world’s leading petroleum producers.

headline: Where Southerners Go to Fill the Tank and Feed the Family
abstract: Are they gas stations that serve food or restaurants that pump gas? A new photography book explores the lure of these restorative community rest stops.
snippet: Are they gas stations that serve food or restaurants that pump gas? A new photography book explores the lure of these restorative community rest stops.
lead_paragraph: New York City has its bodegas. The South has its gas stations.

headline: Democrats Say Biden Hasn’t ‘Made the Case’ on Climate Despite Achievements
abstract: The president likes to talk about his climate agenda as an opportunity to create jobs. Polling shows that may be the wrong way to win over voters.
snippet: The president likes to talk about his climate agenda as an opportunity to create jobs. Polling shows that may be the wrong way to win over voters.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has done more than any president to tackle climate change, but strategists are grappling with an uncomfortable fact: Voters don’t seem to know it.

headline: Shipping Costs Soar in Wake of Red Sea Attacks
abstract: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
snippet: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
lead_paragraph: For about two months, a barrage of missile and drone attacks in the Red Sea by Houthi militants has posed a difficult choice to shipowners using the Suez Canal: risk an airborne strike and pay sharply higher insurance rates, or forgo the canal and take the longer route around Africa, snarling schedules and entailing higher fuel charges.

headline: White House Said to Delay Decision on Enormous Natural Gas Export Terminal
abstract: Before deciding whether to approve it, the Energy Department will analyze the climate impacts of CP2, one of 17 proposed LNG export terminals.
snippet: Before deciding whether to approve it, the Energy Department will analyze the climate impacts of CP2, one of 17 proposed LNG export terminals.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is pausing a decision on whether to approve what would be the largest natural gas export terminal in the United States, a delay that could stretch past the November election and spell trouble for that project and 16 other proposed terminals, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Barricaded Highways and a Deadly Incident as French Farmers Rise Up
abstract: The far right is intent on exploiting the spread of anger across Europe in an agricultural sector that feels alienated.
snippet: The far right is intent on exploiting the spread of anger across Europe in an agricultural sector that feels alienated.
lead_paragraph: A car plowed into a barrier set up by protesting French farmers early on Tuesday, killing a woman and her daughter and injuring her husband, as France faced growing rural fury at perceived overregulation and increased diesel fuel prices.

headline: To Slash Carbon Emissions, Colleges Are Digging Really Deep
abstract: A growing number of colleges and universities are using deep underground pipes to heat and cool their buildings without burning fossil fuels.
snippet: A growing number of colleges and universities are using deep underground pipes to heat and cool their buildings without burning fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: When administrators at Princeton University decided to cut the carbon emissions that came from heating and cooling their campus, they opted for a method that is gaining popularity among colleges and universities.

headline: Exxon Sues to Prevent Climate Proposal From Getting a Shareholder Vote
abstract: The complaint, filed in a U.S. District Court in Texas, said a proposal by activist investors calling for the oil giant to cut emissions faster would not create shareholder value.
snippet: The complaint, filed in a U.S. District Court in Texas, said a proposal by activist investors calling for the oil giant to cut emissions faster would not create shareholder value.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil is suing two activist investors to prevent their proposal calling for emissions cuts at the oil giant from going to a vote of shareholders.

headline: Ukraine Targets Russian Oil Plants, Aiming to Disrupt Military Operations
abstract: Kyiv hit an oil depot on Friday, the latest in recent attacks on such facilities as it seeks to inflict damage away from the largely deadlocked front line.
snippet: Kyiv hit an oil depot on Friday, the latest in recent attacks on such facilities as it seeks to inflict damage away from the largely deadlocked front line.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine hit an oil depot in Russia in a drone attack on Friday, officials on both sides said, the latest in a series of recent assaults targeting Russian oil facilities as Kyiv increasingly seeks to strike critical infrastructure behind Russian lines.

headline: Are You a Super Driver? Some States Want to Help You Go Electric.
abstract: A small share of motorists burns about a third of America’s gasoline, a study found. Switching to electric vehicles would make a huge dent in climate-warming emissions.
snippet: A small share of motorists burns about a third of America’s gasoline, a study found. Switching to electric vehicles would make a huge dent in climate-warming emissions.
lead_paragraph: The key to cutting emissions from cars and light trucks that are heating the planet could lie with the nation’s super drivers, the small percentage of American motorists who drive, on average, about 110 miles per day.

headline: Shell to Sell Its Onshore Nigeria Oil Business for $1.3 Billion
abstract: The energy company’s exit from onshore petroleum drilling in Nigeria is aimed to reduce risks, while it continues to produce oil and gas offshore.
snippet: The energy company’s exit from onshore petroleum drilling in Nigeria is aimed to reduce risks, while it continues to produce oil and gas offshore.
lead_paragraph: Shell said Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its onshore oil and gas business in Nigeria to a group dominated by local companies for $1.3 billion.

headline: How Trump Sidestepped the Tradition of Iowa Pandering
abstract: Presidential candidates often enmesh themselves in the state’s politics to woo voters, but the nature of this race means much less focus on local issues.
snippet: Presidential candidates often enmesh themselves in the state’s politics to woo voters, but the nature of this race means much less focus on local issues.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning in Iowa in the months leading up to the caucuses has traditionally involved candidates’ embracing local customs, visiting familiar locations and championing policies aimed at helping the state’s farm-driven economy.
byline: By Anjali Huynh and Kellen Browning

headline: How This Climate Activist Justifies Political Violence
abstract: “The reason that people contemplate escalation is that there are no risk-free options left,” says the author of "How to Blow Up a Pipeline."
snippet: “The reason that people contemplate escalation is that there are no risk-free options left,” says the author of "How to Blow Up a Pipeline."
lead_paragraph: “The reason that people contemplate escalation is that there are no risk-free options left,” says the author of "How to Blow Up a Pipeline."

headline: Biden Administration to Fine Oil and Gas Companies for Excess Methane
abstract: A plan to impose a fee of $900 to $1,500 on every excess ton of methane emissions would be the first federal price on greenhouse gas pollution.
snippet: A plan to impose a fee of $900 to $1,500 on every excess ton of methane emissions would be the first federal price on greenhouse gas pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced new moves on Friday to curb the release from oil and gas facilities of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is responsible for more than a quarter of the warming the planet is currently experiencing.

headline: BlackRock’s Giant Bet on Infrastructure
abstract: The Wall Street giant agreed to buy Global Infrastructure Partners, whose assets include airports and oil pipelines, in its biggest takeover in 15 years.
snippet: The Wall Street giant agreed to buy Global Infrastructure Partners, whose assets include airports and oil pipelines, in its biggest takeover in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock is already Wall Street’s dominant player in stocks and bonds with $10 trillion in assets. Now the company plans to go big on the business of investing in airports, bridges, oil pipelines and more.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

headline: Trump Dreams of Economic Disaster
abstract: Why, exactly, do so many Americans admire this guy?
snippet: Why, exactly, do so many Americans admire this guy?
lead_paragraph: Did Donald Trump just say that he’s hoping for an economic crash? Not exactly. But what he did say was arguably even worse, especially once you put it in context.

headline: Hertz Will Shrink Electric Fleet After Being Burned by Tesla’s Price Cuts
abstract: The rental car company blamed the sharp drop in the value of electric vehicles and higher repair costs for its decision to sell 20,000 cars.
snippet: The rental car company blamed the sharp drop in the value of electric vehicles and higher repair costs for its decision to sell 20,000 cars.
lead_paragraph: The rental car company Hertz will be selling about one-third of the electric vehicles in its fleet after they lost value more quickly than expected, the company said on Thursday. The drop in value is a blow to the company’s efforts to replace gasoline vehicles with cars that do not produce tailpipe emissions.

headline: Tackling Climate Change in the Birthplace of Oil
abstract: Azerbaijan is where the petroleum era began.
snippet: Azerbaijan is where the petroleum era began.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, the United Nations climate summit known as COP will take place in a petrostate.

headline: Iranian Navy Says It Seized an Oil Tanker Off the Coast of Oman
abstract: The same vessel was involved last year in the U.S. government seizure of Iranian oil that was being transported in violation of American sanctions.
snippet: The same vessel was involved last year in the U.S. government seizure of Iranian oil that was being transported in violation of American sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s navy said it had seized a tanker loaded with crude oil off the coast of Oman on Thursday, apparently in retaliation for the United States confiscating oil from the same ship last year.
byline: By Jenny Gross and Farnaz Fassihi

headline: Top Natural Gas Producers Announce Multibillion-Dollar Merger
abstract: The deal, between Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, would create one of the largest energy producers in the United States.
snippet: The deal, between Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, would create one of the largest energy producers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, two of the largest natural gas producers in the United States, announced plans to merge on Thursday, in an all-stock deal worth $7.4 billion. The new company would become one of the largest energy producers in the United States, with a significant presence in Louisiana and Texas.

headline: Missing Profits May Be a Problem for the Green Transition
abstract: The inability to generate acceptable returns is impeding the switch to renewable energy.
snippet: The inability to generate acceptable returns is impeding the switch to renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: In October, the International Energy Agency issued a brief flare of optimism when it suggested that global carbon emissions from fossil fuels may already have peaked.

headline: U.S. Carbon Emissions Fell in 2023 as Coal Use Tumbled to New Lows
abstract: The drop was big, but emissions will need to fall three times as fast for the rest of the decade if the country wants to meet its climate goals.
snippet: The drop was big, but emissions will need to fall three times as fast for the rest of the decade if the country wants to meet its climate goals.
lead_paragraph: America’s greenhouse gas emissions fell 1.9 percent in 2023, in large part because the burning of coal to produce electricity plummeted to its lowest level in half a century, according to estimates published on Wednesday by the Rhodium Group, a nonpartisan research firm.

headline: World Bank Warns of Energy Price Surge if Mideast War Spreads
abstract: A new economic report predicted a year of weak growth and said the world faced a decade of “wasted opportunity.”
snippet: A new economic report predicted a year of weak growth and said the world faced a decade of “wasted opportunity.”
lead_paragraph: The global economy is at risk of a “wasted” decade and the weakest stretch of growth in 30 years, the World Bank warned on Tuesday, saying a sluggish recovery from the pandemic and crippling wars in Ukraine and the Middle East are expected to weigh heavily on output.

headline: After the Capitol Attack, Companies Pledged to Rethink Political Giving. Did They?
abstract: A new analysis of corporate PAC donations shines light on an opaque political giving landscape.
snippet: A new analysis of corporate PAC donations shines light on an opaque political giving landscape.
lead_paragraph: After a violent mob stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, many businesses and trade groups condemned the attack and pledged to review and shift their approach to political giving, including by halting donations to candidates who voted against certifying the 2020 presidential election.
byline: By Ephrat Livni and Sarah Kessler

headline: An Ecology Minister With an Oil Pedigree Will Lead Global Climate Talks
abstract: Mukhtar Babayev has been appointed to preside over this year’s global climate talks in Azerbaijan.
snippet: Mukhtar Babayev has been appointed to preside over this year’s global climate talks in Azerbaijan.
lead_paragraph: Azerbaijan’s minister of ecology and natural resources, who occupies a relatively obscure position in the country’s authoritarian government, was appointed president of the annual United Nations-sponsored climate summit that will be held in the country in November. The announcement thrusts him into a role defined by the intense pressure of brokering negotiations on one of the most complex crises to ever face humanity.

headline: Red Sea Attacks Leave Tankers With Choice: Accept the Risks or Lose Money
abstract: Some oil tanker traffic continues to go through the Suez Canal, while plentiful global reserves keep crude prices steady.
snippet: Some oil tanker traffic continues to go through the Suez Canal, while plentiful global reserves keep crude prices steady.
lead_paragraph: Attacks on commercial vessels in the Red Sea by the Houthi rebels in Yemen have left oil tanker operators facing an unwelcome calculation: accept the risks of steaming through the danger zone, or lose business.
